Description: Oval black-topped brown ware pottery bowl with rounded base made of very fine Nile silt, burnished horizontally on exterior; interior black and well burnished. White powder on interior adhering to walls.
Curator's comments: This fine oval bowl was considered to be a product of the Tasian period (a period/culture preceding the Badarian) by the excavator, but is one of the very rare examples of black-topping in the corpus of the Tasian culture. The quality of the fabric and the surface treatment are indistinguishable from products of the Badarian period. The bowl was found in the grave of a male in a recess in the side wall covered with a platter of basketry. It contained organic contents identified as a mixture of vegetable fibres and twigs deriving from the basketry mixed with natron.
Bibliographic references: Brunton 1937 / Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture (pp 6, 28, 33; pl.11,16; pl. 14.5 centre bottom)
